item.title: Don't get burned by missing await Calls for Async Code in ASP.NET Core Middleware
item.description: I recently got burned in an upgraded ASP.NET Core server application where a missing `await` statement caused wildly inconsistent and puzzling output failures. While a simple thing to avoid, once introduced it's possible to live with this error for some time before it manifests. In this post I show a scenario where a missing `await` was causing infrequent HTTP response errors, even though the client apparently receives a valid response.
item.author: (https://facebook.com/rickstrahl)

item.title: Phosphine gas in the cloud decks of Venus
item.description: The detection of ~20‚Äâppb of phosphine in Venus clouds by observations in the millimetre-wavelength range from JCMT and ALMA is puzzling, because according to our knowledge of Venus, no phosphine should be there. As the most plausible formation paths do not work, the source could be unknown chemical processes‚Äîmaybe even life?
item.author: (Jim Hoge)

item.title: The Art of Turboing
item.description: I first learned the term ‚Äúturboing‚Äù when I worked second-level telephone technical support at Xerox. It refers to the actions of a customer who goes around the normal technical support process by contacting a senior person in the chain of command.

item.title: The compositor is evil
item.description: First, I want to make it clear that I‚Äôm not accusing the compositor of true evil, which I define roughly as deliberately causing suffering. There‚Äôs unfortunately too much of that in the world. I mean it in the more metaphorical sense that it causes serious problems and forces other parts of the system to be more complex to work around its limitations.

item.title: UBM, and a lament for the software industry
item.description: I grew up in tech as a UBM fan. Ok, not really a fan, but a ‚Äúthere‚Äôs very few voices writing books about ‚Äòhow to write code well‚Äô, and this person seems to know what they‚Äôre doing, so I‚Äôm going to listen to him‚Äù. I read all his books; attended talks he gave at SCNA, and thought for a while that his way was the right way.

item.title: Never Invest in the Business Model
item.description: I am an angel investor. I have been investing personally in early-stage companies, Pre-Seed through Series B, since 2015. I do it not for money but for love of the game; the greatest pleasure to me is to learn from entrepreneurs smarter than me, and help them succeed.

item.title: GNSS Jamming and Spoofing, aka Galileo's Authentication Algorithm Part 3 - Articles
item.description: Welcome to part 3 of my series on OSNMA, the proposed Galileo Navigation Message Authentication protocol. This part can be read independently from part 1 and part 2, but it might be useful to read the introduction to part 1. This post attempts to explain GPS (GNSS) jamming and spoofing, so it might be a useful read even if you don‚Äôt care about Galileo or its authentication. As usual, I‚Äôve been helped tremendously by Daniel Est√©vez & many other researchers and Galileo professionals, and again I am very greatful for all the links, corrections, suggestions and knowledge you provided.

item.title: Febraury 13, 2020 - Blazor TreeView GridLines and starting the FormView component
item.description:
Today Fritz finished the GridLine implementation for the TreeView Blazor component and built a sample to show how the FormView should behave.
Questions: 15:13 - Does a TreeView really need grid lines? 44:38 - Do the TreeNodes register with the parent in Onlnitalized? 45:46 - Can TreeNodes register with the parent TreeNode as they're drawn? 47:41 - This is as close to a "Pattern" with Blazor: Child Components register with their Parent component 51:14 - Should I create my 'Creative Coding' stream? What worked for you and why did you start? 1:39:15 - Am I the only one that gets an SSL error for docs.microsoft.com? 2:07:40 - With Git push, shouldn't it be pushing the current branch if you don't provide a branch name?
Source Code at https://github.com/FritzAndFriends/BlazorWebFormsComponents Watch live at https://www.twitch.tv/csharpfritz
item.author: (Jeffrey T. Fritz)

item.title: February 14, 2020 - Blazor Coding with Squirrel
item.description:
In a fun-filled episode that was just NUTS to make, Fritz dons a squirrel costume provided by viewers as he writes code. After about 30 minutes of shenanigans and more puns than you can shake a stick at, Fritz gets back into working on the BlazorWebFormsComponents.
He continues working on the FormView component for Blazor, adding support for FooterTemplates. He is challenged by the viewers to use the Peanut Font while coding (http://www.fontriver.com/font/peanut/) and spends 15 minutes in that configuration. He adds the Pager feature to the FormView along with appropriate integration tests to show it off.
1:22:11 - Would you recommend a novice developer learn command line Git? Or is a GUI acceptable in 2002?
Source Code at https://github.com/FritzAndFriends/BlazorWebFormsComponents Watch live at https://www.twitch.tv/csharpfritz
item.author: (Jeffrey T. Fritz)

item.description: .NET 5 Release Candidate 1 (RC1) is now available and is ready for evaluation. Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs new in this release: Blazor WebAssembly performance improvements Blazor component virtualization Blazor WebAssembly prerendering Browser compatibility analyzer for Blazor WebAssembly Blazor JavaScript isolation and object references Blazor file input support Custom validation class attributes in Blazor Blazor support for ontoggle event Model binding DateTime as UTC Control Startup class activation Open API Specification (Swagger) on-by-default in ASP.NET Core API projects Better F5 Experience for ASP.NET Core API Projects SignalR parallel hub invocations Added Messagepack support in SignalR Java client Kestrel endpoint-specific options via configuration See the .NET 5 release notes for additional details and known issues.

item.title: Leaked database indicates Chinese intelligence has probed senior Australian politicians | Sky News Australia
item.description:
The families of Australian politicians have been the target of open-source surveillance by a Chinese company that claims to have done work on behalf of Chinese intelligence, cyber security experts claim.
In an exclusive interview with Sky News Australia, cyber security analysts Robert Potter and Chris Balding have detailed the incredible scope of the espionage which they claim has targeted the most senior politicians in Australia.
The men claim a leaked database from a company called Shenzen Zhenhua Data indicates an intelligence assessment was carried out on the children or spouses of Prime Minister Scott Morrison, former Ambassador in Washington, Joe Hockey, current Ambassador, Arthur Sinodinos and Chair of the Intelligence Committee, Andrew Hastie.
The company alleged to have produced the database - Shenzen Zhenhua Data ‚Äì has ties to Chinese intelligence.
Mr Balding ‚Äì a professor at Fulbright University - said his international group of cyber-security experts had gone to great lengths to verify the database over the past 18 months, including having the data analysed by some intelligence agencies globally.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôve done extensive background research to basically vet the individuals, the data where this comes from, and so we feel very confident in saying that not only does the company claim to work with Chinese military, Chinese security and intelligence, but that we can actually track the individuals that have written this code, the individuals that own this company and who they are connected to, who sites on the board of directors and that, yes they do actually in fact either work for the PLA or the Ministry of State Security,‚Äù he said.
‚ÄúThis information is being used by the Chinese state to try and target influence operations or intelligence operations around the world.‚Äù
In total, 2.4 million people and 650,000 organisations have been the target of the open-source surveillance activities, according to the leaked files, some of which have been seen by Sky News Australia and The Australian.
Some of the big names featured in the Shenzen Zhenhua database include US President Donald Trump, Nancy Pelosi, and her entire family including her brother Thomas and her children Alexandra and Paul, along with Shinzo Abe, Vladimir Putin and his children.
There are also members of the British Royal Family and high-profile journalists.
A Chinese activist whistle-blower copied the database and leaked it to an international group of cyber-security analysts 18 months ago.
The homepage of the system is titled, ‚ÄúThe Internet Big Data Military Intelligence System.‚Äù
Publications in Italy, Germany, UK, Canada, US, Japan, India and Australia, including the AFR, have been shared the data in recent months.
Mr Potter added: ‚ÄúWe put together a team of people, people like myself from defence backgrounds, former intelligence officers, current intelligence, current intelligence officers and we pulled our resources together.‚Äù
Mr Potter, who has recently done cyber defence work for the US State Department in Washington through his company Internet 2.0, said Shenzen Zhenhua Data was gathering data globally and sending it back to a server in China, with the intelligence split into different databases that included ship-tracking to military and defence officials, intellectual property and patent databases, professors of universities and decision makers in politics.
‚ÄúI would suggest that every person who has a profile in this database has probably been the victim of a pretty extensive breach of their privacy, not just in terms of the level of scraping that has occurred form the open source, collating that into a profile rendered in another country, taken from platforms where they didn‚Äôt really consent to this information being shared in that way,‚Äù he said.
‚ÄúI think most people who sit in senior roles in government would expect a degree of intelligence activity, they probably wouldn‚Äôt expect it to come from the privacy sector.
Image: AP
